pros: There were some bureaucratic headaches that I had to work through bc of the university's administration, but the department I worked for was amazing. Great people to work with who all wanted to contribute to a good work environment. The union stuck up for us very well.
cons: Just the usual academic weirdness that comes with any university. They won't do much recruiting for you unless you're an already prestigious program) and they will cancel your classes if you don't have a high enough enrollment. And they won't necessarily tell you this is happening until right before the semester starts, meaning course prep as a new instructor can be a nightmare. But this can happen at most any university and is not specific to URI.

review_title: Highly toxic; awful leadership on staff and board
pros:
Nice campus
Access to the library
cons:
I would give this place no stars whatsoever. Dramatically underpaid for efforts - you will be working nights and weekends. My boss chastised and critiqued myself as well as my colleagues on a daily basis - and not in a constructive criticism way; she actually asked me once to tell a coworker to “buy pants that fit.” The state of RI could not contain this woman’s ego. Very insecure control freak. There were also confidential moves happening at the time I was there and she was directly accusatory of the team for “leaking” information. Sorry, no one actually cared - then or now - and it was ultimately the best move for the Foundation bc this woman was suddenly less important as a result. Her negativity and fears completely impeded to lead her ability to lead effectively and in alignment with URI values. 

It amazes me she still has a job - all her kids have graduated just let her go!

review_title: A lot of great colleagues, but salaries need major realignment and some longtime administrators need to move on
pros:
Great people to work with
Good environment
The University is rapidly expanding and moving forward
cons:
Some longtime administrators are holding back progress and can't trust up-and-coming leaders to make decisions.
Some salaries are way out of alignment with market values.  The leadership of many departments know this and have come up with creative ways to give higher salaries through some wacky justifications.  The state really needs to let URI take control of their own personnel and adjust salaries in place without having to jump through hoops in order to recruit and retain bright people.  I hear they are making progress on this.

review_title: Like the natural environment, and a lot people there, but not the working environment,
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant/Lab Instructor in Kingston, RI
pros: Quite place, beautiful campus, very near to the beach. Summer and winter break. Salary is in the middle compare with teaching assistants in other universities. Diversity, you will meet people of different ages, countries, races.
cons:
Teaching assistant is used as matching position for professors. So actually, you work as both teaching assistant and research assistant. That means, you do two jobs but only get one income. Grad students, especially international students, are absolutely abused, from my view. 

Curriculum for both grads and under grads are outdated and too far away from the real-world application in industry. Course design should have and could have been more practical and more related to the real-world application.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistant - College of Pharmacy
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kingston, RI
pros: Great working environment, Professors and students are generally friendly and helpful. There is a great community of researchers here that work together. Benefits are good, campus is nice, and location close to Rhode Island beaches as well as Boston and Providence is also convenient. This is a great place to work!
cons: The pay is quite low, even for a graduate student. Working full time hours at the University doesn't generally supply a livable wage, so many students (myself included) have to seek other part-time employment to make a little extra money.

pros: Good education, it's nice because it's free if you get an assistantship either teaching or researching. Nothing quite like someone paying you to get your masters.
cons: The administration is ridiculous in terms of red tape and contract negotiations. The grad assistants union has been in negotiations for a year and a half and the admin can't agree to give us a living wage. Currently grad students at URI qualify for food stamps - it's hard to do quality work when you're worried about feeding yourself.

pros: I have a great deal of interaction with many different departments at the university. Staff at the top leadership positions are accessible and generally supportive. Majority of staff in administrative jobs care about the quality of their work.
cons: Too many internal procedures and added steps slow down getting things done. The state mandated policies also limit creativity and innovation. You must have patience if you are trying to change any internal procedure.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Kingston, RI
pros: We were unionize his grad students, so I felt very taken care of. The pay wasn't the greatest, but that's what you expect is a grad student. My professors were phenomenal, and made sure that school came first. They also made attempts to get to know us outside of class. If you were looking at URI for graduate school, and were offered a position I would highly recommend it
cons: With any university it's going to be a little cumbersome. Parking is probably the worst thing you have to deal with

pros: Worked at the URI Media and Technology Helpdesk for about 5 years. One of the most organized little departments compared to the rest of the University. Offers students a professional working environment during their undergraduate years to give them experience for the real world.
cons: Gets very hectic during the heavy seasons, i.e. beginning of the year, finals, etc.. Must have a LOT of patience with many clients because of their level of understanding with certain technology. Phone calls may take up to two hours with a client for a tasks that may take15 minutes to an experienced user.

review_title: Everyone will have a different experience... but mostly good!
pros:
Training (at least at the time) was comprehensive and helpful. HRL (Housing and Residential Life) did a good job of helping RAs meet other RAs they could build relationships with to do better at the job--and just be friends with!

The job itself is what I like to call a many-hats-wearing gig- anything that isn't under someone else's title that has to do with residents generally falls to you. You can make this job what you want, though, so you can do as much as you want or do the required tasks and still do well. Going above and beyond is rewarded, though!

Staffs are generally well-balanced and allow you to make friendships and work with people that you normally may not get the chance to. I learned a lot. Supervisors in my experience were great--but leadership styles were incredibly varied. One on one meetings with supervisors were common (I believe required) and they were a great opportunity to improve communication and get help or flexibility if you needed it.

The schedule is for the most part flexible. Other RAs will generally be happy to switch on calls or office hours with you. Schedules- and on calls- can certainly get crazy though. You will get war stories- funny, terrible, sweet, or some combination. The folks at student conduct will back you up to a T though, so you have that going for you when students try to get out of write ups and make up crazy lies. 

Overall, I loved the position and miss it!!
cons: The typical state university (and any university and company really) politics and bureacratic nonsense applies to URI. I have also heard through the grapevine they are restructuring decision making designs and taking less input from staff and students, which I think is a step in the wrong direction. The training structure for RAs has also changed.

review_title: Graduate student funding is an afterthought at URI!
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Kingston, RI
pros: Lots of opportunity to build, strengthen, and diversify your teaching experience. Faculty is often open to graduate assistant ideas on adding new courses and improving existing course content, presentation, and organization.
cons: No guaranteed funding for summers, horrible health insurance, no dental coverage, policies frequently change from year-to-year, poor leadership and management with zero accountability at every level.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Great, had the opportunity to work on my own time. Also was being paid to learn, rather than paying to learn. Not having to commute very far for work is always a plus. I could walk 5 minutes from my dorm and be at work.
cons: The pay isn't really that good in comparison to the amount of tuition that I have to pay. But besides that there aren't really any cons.

pros: Tuition is free, beautiful campus, close to beaches, nice area to live in
cons: State workers here are mostly miserable and avoid work at all costs. Additionally, there is a lack of central authority and leadership, thus almost zero accountability. This is true for both staff and faculty.

review_title: Comparable salary and benefits to other major universities.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Narragansett, RI
pros: Beautiful campus, especially the Bay campus in Narragansett. Salary and benefits for graduate research assistants are comparable to other major universities in New England.  As with other major universities, your experience is very department dependent.
cons: Inconsistent infrastructure depending on the department. Some departments have very poor infrastructure some are modern and cutting edge. Due to the nature of being a state university the outsourcing of contract work has had mixed results.

pros: Top notch people. Collaborative and friendly atmosphere. Students are eager to learn and many work while also in Univ. They don't act like they are entitled or spoiled.
cons: Main campus is in Kingston, RI versus Providence. But the commute is relatively easy, since even Providence (RI's biggest city) doesn't have the degree of traffic problems typically metropolitan areas (e.g. Boston).

pros: Free tuition, health insurance, and stipend. My department was great but others not so lucky
cons: Health Insurance is not good, stipend is well below the national average, funding isn't guaranteed for graduate students.

review_title: It's all about what you make of it
pros: You can get a great practical education here if you are willing to put in the required work. Treat classes and research as job training and you will stay motivated.
cons: Below average compensation and facilities. My adviser was next to useless so I had to figure everything out for myself which ended up teaching me a lot.

pros: Nice area to live, but cost of living is high. Community is full of professional, educated people.
cons:
There is a huge amount of favoritism at URI and politics are rampant. Faculty members have a pretty good life; they teach, and can go about their business, relatively insulated from the dramas of the politics, but middle and lower management are subject to a lot of abuse. Leadership is non existent, but management and micromanagement are rampant.
If you want to advance, this is not a good place to do it. Plan on getting some experience and moving on.

pros: It's a long training process, but it's fun.
cons: Whereas many schools offer room and board remissions, at URI RA's pay upfront, and then are paid biweekly based on the cost of housing (it's a flat fee that applies to all RAs, so that RA's placed in nicer dorms and older dorms have the same pay and costs).  This means you are taxed on it.  It's great for those on a free ride, but for others, it kinda sucks.

job_title: Clinical Assistant Professor in Kingston, RI
pros: I loved my coworkers like a family, wonderful place to work with generally great students
cons: Faculty senate does not recognize non-tenure track faculty as having a vote in faculty governance. They cannot serve on faculty senate, nor do they have a vote that counts in any other matters at the college or university level.  This really needs to change, particularly for those colleges such as Nursing and Pharmacy that have a high concentration of non-tenure track faculty

job_title: Classroom Media Assistant in Kingston, RI
pros: A lot of down time allows for some classwork to be completed during work. Probably the best on campus job that you can have.
cons: The school won't let you work over 20 hours a week and the pay is minimum wage. That said there are ways to get raises so that you can make a little more. You'd still make more interning somewhere though. General scheduling isn't too good as well.

pros: Talking to a lot of people. University-work-spirit in basketball games and big events is important and fun. A lot of hype.
cons: A lot of standing. Maybe sometimes repeating the same phrases to people for help or other things can be annoying, but not that bad.

pros: URI is a good environment to work. Employees are so nice to talk with.  i would recommend people to work there.
cons: the benefit is not that good. as a graduate assisstantship you have to pay 80% of the service fee like shuttle, gym and library

pros: Academic freedom, flexible work schedule, descent level of stress, and great professors to with with and get advices. State University
cons: It is supported by the state, which means the cash flow depends on the economy. To subsidies the state portion, tuition is raised steadely

pros: This is a great experience to learn and grow as a student in college. There are many opportunities to mature as a person. I love the work that I do which is great.
cons: The job is 24/7 and that can be hard. HRL does not run efficiently. Many workers lose motivation for the job.

pros: They are pretty flexible with the scheduling, depending on the position, of course, so working while in classes isn't a problem.
cons: They limit you to 12 hours per week in order to protect you from overloading yourself while in classes, but don't raise the maximum number of hours you're allowed to work if you aren't enrolled as a full time student.

pros: Working at URI-GSO is a challenging yet rewarding experience. The work is consistently changing and project involvement is key to success.
cons: Management working with URI can be difficult due to the strange politics that can occur at the University.

job_title: URI ITMS Student Employee in Kingston, RI
pros: Great flexibility.  Employers understand students have obligations outside of work.  Nice environment.  Around other like minded students working on similar projects, so help is always an earshot away.  Builds a strong community.  Still sharing friendships with those I met while employed
cons: 9-5 hours make it difficult to find time for hours.

review_title: Review of URI for teaching assistants
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Kingston, RI
pros: As a teaching assistant, I enjoy the intellectual engagement that working and studying at URI provides. I have freedom in developing my course syllabi.
cons: Pay for graduate students it tough to live on, but the free education and health benefits to help. It can be challenging to juggle one's own studies with the teaching.

review_title: Grading is the bread; teaching, the butter
pros: Great opportunity to gain experience teaching and leading a large group
cons: Most of the time was spent grading students' homework

pros: easy to share and accomplish your ideas, no micromanaging from higher staff, lots of money in the budget to work with
cons: a little bit too relaxed, lack of hard deadlines and oversight, hard to get things approved when needed

review_title: Career advancement opportunities within the Department of Facilities Services should be gender blind
pros: wonderful people, both co-workers and students
cons: gender discrimination against women workers/double standard for promotion and career advancement within the department of facilities services

pros: Tuition Waiver. Health insurance. A collective bargaining unit.
cons: Stipend consistent with poverty. Very little administrative support. Many department chairs mislead or simply lie to GAs, as well as exploit them.

pros: Great people, atmosphere and beautiful campus to be celebrated by everyone across New England. Proud to be an alum and employee
cons: Nothing comes to mind. Traffic patterns can be troublesome and the abundance of towing and ticketing that goes on.

review_title: Undergraduate Pharmaceutical Engineering Research Assistant lifestyle.

pros: It has been an incredible learning experience. I hope the skills I have obtained will aid me in finding a job in my field of study.
cons: It's difficult to move forward quickly as an undergraduate.

review_title: Your experience depends on your PI, do your research

pros: Depending on PI it is a great experience, very helpful, TA positions available to offset graduate student costs
cons: Low pay, lack of motivation, negative energy, lack of information for new graduate students

review_title: Great environment, wonderful people and rewarding work.

cons: Unable to qualify for employment when you are not a student.

pros: Great opportunity to learn more one on one from professors, interact with students and help them in ways you wish you were helped.
cons: Budget limitations hold the department back so you learn to compromise and adjust accordingly

pros: Flexible, Easy to pick up. Has it's own parking lot. Snacks and drinks are available within the library.
cons: Boring, Not challenging, Co workers are elderly. Mostly a very quiet environment - stay away if you like background noise.

pros: Great community, committed professionals, lots of room for personal growth

pros: general support, place is nice, people are nice
